title: Natural Balance Tears Ophthalmic (Eye): Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for Natural Balance Tears ophthalmic (eye) on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) is used to relieve dry, irritated [eyes](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/picture-of-the-eyes). Common causes for [dry eyes](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/eye-health-dry-eyes) include wind, sun, heating/air conditioning, computer use/reading, and certain [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx).This product may contain 1 or more the following ingredients: carboxymethylcellulose, glycol, among others. [Eye](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/picture-of-the-eyes) lubricants keep the [eye](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/ss/slideshow-eye-conditions-overview) moist, help to protect the [eye](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/video/eye-anatomy) from injury and infection, and decrease symptoms of dry [eyes](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/ss/slideshow-eye-conditions-overview) such as burning, [itching](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/skin-conditions-pruritus), and feeling as if something is in the eye. How to use Natural Balance Tears 0.1 %-0.3 % Eye Drops Follow all directions on the product package. If you have any questions, ask your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Do not use a solution that has changed color or is cloudy. Certain brands (containing [glycerin](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-20275/glycerin+topical/details) with polysorbates, among other ingredients) may have a milky appearance. This is okay as long as the solution does not change color. Some [eye](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/picture-of-the-eyes) drops need to be shaken before use. Check the label to see if you should shake your product before using. Usually, drops may be used as often as needed. Ointments are usually used 1 to 2 times daily as needed. If using an ointment once a day, it may be best to use it at [bedtime](https://www.webmd.com/parenting/childs-bedtime). To apply [eye](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/ss/slideshow-eye-conditions-overview) ointment/drops/gels: Wash hands first. To avoid contamination, be careful not to touch the dropper or top of the ointment tube or let it touch your [eye](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/video/eye-anatomy). Always replace the cap tightly after each use. Tilt your head back, look up, and pull down the lower eyelid to make a pouch. For drops/gels, place the dropper directly over the eye and squeeze out 1 or 2 drops as needed. Look down and gently close your eye for 1 or 2 minutes. Place one finger at the corner of the eye near the nose and apply gentle pressure. This will prevent the [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) from draining away from the eye. For an ointment, hold the tube directly over the eye and gently squeeze a small strip (one-fourth of an inch or roughly 6 millimeters) of ointment into the pouch. Release the eyelid, close the eye, and slowly roll your eye in all directions to spread the medication. Blot away any extra ointment from around the eye with a clean tissue. If you are also using another kind of eye medication (such as drops or ointments), wait at least 5 minutes before applying other [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx). Use eye drops before eye ointments to allow the eye drops to enter the eye. If you wear [contact lenses](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/contact-lenses-colored-soft-hard-toric-bifocal), remove them before using most kinds of eye lubricants. Ask your doctor or pharmacist when you may replace your [contact lenses](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/eye-vision-tv/video-how-to-avoid-contact-lens-discomfort). There are a few types of eye lubricants (some that contain polysorbates) that can be used while wearing contact lenses. Check the package to see if you can wear your contact lenses while using your product. Tell your doctor if your condition lasts or gets worse after 3 days. Side Effects [Vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/vision-basics) may be temporarily blurred when this product is first used. Also, minor burning/stinging/irritation may temporarily occur. If any of these effects last or get worse, tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) promptly. If your doctor has directed you to use this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), remember that your doctor has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. Tell your doctor right away if you have any serious side effects, including: [eye pain](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/eye-pain-causes-symptoms-diagnosis-treatment), change in vision, continued [eye](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/picture-of-the-eyes) redness/irritation. A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your doctor or pharmacist. In the US - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to FDA at 1-800-FDA-1088 or at www.fda.gov/medwatch. In Canada - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to Health Canada at 1-866-234-2345. Precautions Before using this product, tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) if you are allergic to it; or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients, which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your pharmacist for more details. If you have any health problems, consult your doctor or pharmacist before using this product. After you apply this product, your [vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/vision-basics) may become temporarily blurred. Do not drive, use machinery, or do any activity that requires clear vision until you can do it safely. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your doctor and [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Overdose This medicine may be harmful if swallowed. If someone has overdosed and has serious symptoms such as passing out or [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments), call 911. Otherwise, call a poison control center right away. US residents can call their local poison control center at 1-800-222-1222. Canada residents can call a provincial poison control center. Some products contain preservatives that may damage [contact lenses](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/contact-lenses-colored-soft-hard-toric-bifocal) or cause irritation in persons with [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). For more information, check your product package or talk with your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional. This [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) is usually used only as needed. Refer to storage information printed on the package. Protect ointments from freezing. Some preservative-free drops that come in single-use vials/droppers should be discarded either immediately after use or up to 12 hours after opening. Check your product package to see when you should discard your preservative-free product. If you have any questions about storage, ask your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your pharmacist or local waste disposal company.
